content.source_1: Boyland, E. J., Nolan, S., Kelly, B., et al. (2016). American Journal of Clinical Nutrition — Systematic review and meta-analysis finds that exposure to unhealthy food and beverage advertising increases immediate energy intake in children, implicating advertising in diet-related harms.
content.source_2: Saffer, H., & Chaloupka, F. (2000). Journal of Health Economics — Cross-country analysis shows comprehensive tobacco advertising bans reduce consumption, implying that advertising increases use of a harmful product.
content.source_3: Grabe, S., Ward, L. M., & Hyde, J. S. (2008). Psychological Bulletin — Meta-analysis links exposure to thin-ideal media imagery (common in advertising) to increased body dissatisfaction among women, a risk factor for disordered eating and poor mental health.
content.source_4: Benham, L. (1972). Journal of Law and Economics — Study of U.S. states finds that allowing advertising for eyeglasses is associated with significantly lower prices, suggesting advertising can enhance competition and benefit consumers.
content.source_5: Ataman, M. B., van Heerde, H. J., & Mela, C. F. (2010). Journal of Marketing Research — Longitudinal evidence indicates advertising’s long-term sales elasticities are generally small, suggesting ads often shift brand share rather than expanding overall demand (limiting aggregate harm).
content.source_6: Wakefield, M. A., Loken, B., & Hornik, R. C. (2010). The Lancet — Review concludes well-designed mass media campaigns (a form of advertising) can improve public health behaviors, including reducing smoking and increasing seatbelt use, showing advertising can yield net benefits.
